I took some time to think about it... sorry for the delay but it was 
worth it (at least for me).

>>It is the right way to deal with a null 
>>argument?  I don't think so.
> 
> What do you think is the right way?


throw an IllegalArgumentException when your method receives an argument 
that is illegal (or you can also exit the method, but this won't give 
much information to the calling method).

Some words about the assert keyword in JDK1.4:

Unit testing is good but having unit tested your program is not a proof 
that there is no bug in your program.  And having a 100% coverage is not 
a proof, just a sign that you have to use another testing strategy to 
find other bugs.

Every test strategy has its limits, so does unit testing.  Typically in 
unit testing, _you_ set the object to a particular state and then apply 
the method you test.  But what happens if your object is not in that 
particular state before the method is called?  How many times did you 
find bugs that were discovered only because the system was in a 
particular state?

If you use the assert keyword to ensure that your system is in a valid 
state, you will be able (hopefully) to detect bugs that are not due to 
the object's method but to the object's state.
